results.headline: Those Slings and Arrows of Adolescence Sting
results.display_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days

results.summary_short: The pains of adolescence are exposed in the third film based on the “Diary of a Wimpy Kid” books.

results.headline: Splitting but Not Leaving

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Celeste and Jesse Forever

results.summary_short: “Celeste and Jesse Forever” explores a relationship between a man and a woman that’s no longer predicated by mutual desire.

results.headline: She’s a Vigilante, and a Belly Dancer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Assassin's Bullet

results.summary_short: A former F.B.I. field agent (Christian Slater) is enticed back to his old duties in “Assassin’s Bullet.”

results.headline: Fortune’s Thin Thread, Catching, Not Releasing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 360

results.summary_short: Fernando Meirelles’s “360,” with Anthony Hopkins and Jude Law, is a multistrand narrative that follows an ensemble cast from Vienna to Phoenix, exploring the cause-and-effect nature in a string of affairs.

results.headline: The Billionaire Versus the Little Guy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You've Been Trumped

results.summary_short: “You’ve Been Trumped” is Anthony Baxter’s hostile portrait of Donald Trump as he embarks on a grandiose new project in Scotland.

results.headline: Rock Musician Shrouded in Mystery of What Might Have Been

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Searching for Sugar Man

results.summary_short: A Swedish filmmaker seeks to solve the mystery of a Detroit musician who disappeared after his first album bombed, but whose songs became immensely popular in 1970s South Africa.

results.headline: Giving Voice to a Big-Picture Thinker

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry

results.summary_short: In “Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry,” the doings of that vocal Chinese artist are documented because of a young American’s serendipitous decision.

results.headline: Timid Close Encounters of the Small-Town Kind

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Watch

results.summary_short: In “The Watch,” directed by Akiva Schaffer, Ben Stiller is a do-good leader of an incompetent community watch group that discovers a hive of aliens in its hometown.

results.headline: Choreographed Romance

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Step Up: Revolution

results.summary_short: Invigorating dance numbers in this fourth “Step Up” movie are made all the more entertaining by the 3-D technology.

results.headline: Singer Made His Mark, Then He Left It
results.display_title: Shut Up and Play the Hits

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shut Up and Play the Hits

results.summary_short: The documentary “Shut Up and Play the Hits” covers the last concert by LCD Soundsystem, fronted by James Murphy.

results.headline: Vengeance and Patience

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sacrifice

results.summary_short: A tale of revenge plays out over years in the Mandarin epic “Sacrifice.”

results.headline: Danger and a Stranger

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rites of Spring

results.summary_short: The plots of young adults converge with the legend of Wormface in the horror film “Rites of Spring.”

results.headline: Misery Loves Company and Verbal Skirmishing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nuit #1

results.summary_short: In the debut feature “Nuit #1,” a couple meet, have sex and embark on a rocky relationship.

results.headline: Raunchy Steps Toward Becoming a Father

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Klown

results.summary_short: In the Danish comedy “Klown” a man on vacation tries to prove his paternal potential with a 12-year-old nephew.

results.headline: Meet the Murderer, the Best of a Bad Lot

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Killer Joe

results.summary_short: “Killer Joe,” written by Tracy Letts and directed by William Friedkin, finds Matthew McConaughey as a psycho among a family of ne’er-do-wells.

results.headline: A First-Date Tale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Falling Overnight

results.summary_short: “Falling Overnight” offers a detailed view at the twists and turns of a first date.

results.headline: Food and Fury

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Burning Man

results.summary_short: A hard-charging chef in Sydney who is raising his 8-year-old son is alienating people left and right — then a car accident changes things.

results.headline: Corporate Power Takes Aim at Independent Film

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big Boys Gone Bananas!*

results.summary_short: The Dole Food Company tried to block the release of Fredrik Gertten’s 2009 film “Bananas!” — and he fights back.

results.headline: From the Dark, Illumination

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Abendland

results.summary_short: The documentary “Abendland,” directed by Nikolaus Geyrhalter, uses images of Europe at night to explore the ideas of constructed nationalism and political community.

results.headline: She’s Everything He Wants, and Therein Lies the Problem

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ruby Sparks

results.summary_short: “Ruby Sparks,” written by and starring Zoe Kazan, is a variation of the Pygmalion myth, featuring Paul Dano as a struggling novelist.
